name: Deck
description: The flat board you stand on. Made of layered maple wood.
example: Larger decks (8.5 inches or wider) provide stability for vert skating, while smaller decks (less than 8 inches wide) are preferred for street skating.

name: Trucks
description: The T-shaped metal parts that attach the wheels to the deck.
example: Tighter trucks are stable for ramp tricks, while looser trucks allow for easier turning on flat ground.

name: Wheels
description: Round parts made of polyurethane, allowing the skateboard to roll.
example: Harder wheels (99A-101A) are ideal for smooth surfaces and technical tricks, softer wheels (78A-87A) are better for street and rough surfaces.

name: Bearings
description: Small metal rings that fit inside the wheels to allow them to spin.
example: Higher ABEC ratings indicate greater precision and efficiency, suitable for smoother and faster rides.

name: Grip Tape
description: A gritty, adhesive-backed paper applied to the top of the deck for traction.
example: Coarser grip tape provides more traction for tricks, while finer grip tape is easier on shoes for cruising.

name: Risers
description: Plastic or rubber pads placed between the trucks and deck to increase clearance and reduce vibration.
example: Risers can help prevent wheel bite during sharp turns and are often used in cruising and longboarding.

name: Hardware
description: Screws and bolts that secure the trucks to the deck.
example: Longer hardware is necessary when using riser pads, while standard length is sufficient for most setups without risers.

name: Bushings
description: Rubber-like components in the trucks that allow for turning and pivoting.
example: Softer bushings are preferred for lighter riders or those looking for easier turning, while harder bushings provide more stability.

name: Skate Tool
description: A multi-functional tool designed specifically for skateboards, used to adjust trucks, change wheels, and fit bearings.
example: A skate tool is essential for quick adjustments before a session or for assembling a new setup, featuring sockets for the axle, kingpin, and mounting hardware nuts.
